key_title: Key to the species of Plantago

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Plantaginaceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Plantaginaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1999). Plantaginaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves opposite on elongated branched stems; plant with glandular hairs
Leaves all in a basal rosette; plant almost glabrous or with eglandular hairs
Flowers usually cleistogamous; corolla-lobes erect, rarely spreading, imbricate or valvate, persistent; anthers not exserted
Flowers chasmogamous; corolla-lobes spreading or reflexed; anthers exserted
Leaves more or less elliptic, mostly 10–30 cm long and 1.5–5 cm wide; spike usually 10–40 cm long, lower flowers less crowded than those above; often robust perennial with many adventitious roots
Leaves narrow-elliptic to narrow-obovate, mostly 3–15 cm long and 0.5–1.5 cm wide; spike usually 10–25 cm long, all flowers more or less uniformly spaced; small slender annual with a thin taproot
Leaves usually pinnately or bipinnately lobed, pilose; corolla-tube hairy in lower half
Leaves entire or toothed (sometimes pinnately lobed in P. triandra), glabrous to pilose; corolla-tube glabrous
Ovules and seeds 8–16; leaf-lamina ovate to broad-elliptic, 2–12 cm wide, with the petiole about as long as lamina
Ovules and seeds 2–5 (except for P. triandra); leaf-lamina either less than 2 cm wide, or if ever wider, then petiole shorter than lamina
Peduncles with conspicuous longitudinal ridges; anterior sepals fused; spike dense; common weed of modified sites
Peduncles without conspicuous longitudinal ridges; sepals all free; spike dense or open; mostly native species of natural habitats
Bracts on lower part of inflorescence much longer than sepals; anther appendage membranous, of similar length to body of anther
Bracts on lower part of inflorescence shorter than or about as long as sepals; anther appendage not membranous, much shorter than body of anther
Bracts on lower part of inflorescence terete; peduncles with more or less appressed, antrorse, curled hairs
Bracts on lower part of inflorescence acuminate; peduncles with long, spreading silky hairs
Taproot not developed, rootstock often branched and plants colony-forming; bracts glabrous or sometimes with a ciliate margin; high-altitude perennials (except for the invasive P. triandra)

Taproot developed, usually unbranched and plants usually not colonial (except in P. gaudichaudii); bracts pilose or glabrous; mostly low-altitude annuals or perennials (but P. antarctica often subalpine)
Spikes 1–9 (–13)-flowered
Spikes 10-many-flowered
Seeds 8–42 per capsule; spikes 1–3-flowered, peduncles shorter than leaves; weed of sporting greens
Seeds fewer than 8 per capsule; inflorescence not as above; native alpine and subalpine species
Leaves usually less than 5 mm wide; spikes 1–3-flowered, peduncles c. as long as leaves at anthesis and not or hardly elongating in fruit; rosettes usually less than 5 cm diam
Leaves usually more than 5 mm wide; spikes usually more than 3-flowered, held among leaf-bases at anthesis but peduncles usually longer than leaves in fruit; rosettes usually more than 5 cm diam
Leaves green, glabrous to lightly pubescent, mostly 3-veined, lateral veins much less conspicuous on upper surface than midrib; fruiting spikes mostly 0.8–3 cm long
Leaves blue-green or grey-green, pubescent to tomentose, mostly with 5 or more veins, lateral veins virtually or quite as conspicuous on upper surface as midrib; fruiting spikes mostly 3–10 cm long
Perennials; capsule less than 3.5 mm long, unbeaked but often with persistent style-base
Annuals or short-lived perennials; capsule either 3.5–5 mm long or smaller and beaked; mostly north-western
Capsule with a more or less cylindric beak, the apex truncate and minutely lobed
Capsule unbeaked or with a conical beak, more or less acute and not lobed at apex
Capsule less than 2 mm diam., distinctly constricted above midway to form a short, conical beak; bracts and sepals usually pale or dark brown
Capsule 2.2–3.5 mm diam., not distinctly beaked; bracts and sepals usually dark brown or blackish
Sepals with keel glabrous
Sepals with keel pilose
Sepals usually 2.1–3.5 mm long; spikes mostly less than 6 cm long, flowers crowded; leaves thick-textured
Sepals usually 1.5–2 mm long; spikes mostly more than 6 cm long and flowers usually not crowded; leaves rather thin-textured
Sepals usually 2.8–3.5 mm long; leaf-axils with tufts of red-brown to golden-brown hairs 2–6 mm long
Sepals usually 1.5–2.8 mm long; leaf-axils with tufts of white or yellow-brown hairs less than 2 mm long
Leaves linear to linear-elliptic, at least 15 times longer than wide, glabrous or pilose with some hairs longer than 1 mm
Leaves narrow-elliptic, usually 5–10 times longer than wide, pilose with hairs to 1 mm long, rarely more
Sepals usually 1.5–2 mm long; anthers less than 1 mm long; leaves mostly 8–40 mm wide; spikes usually loose at maturity
Sepals usually 2.2–3 mm long; anthers 1 mm long or more; leaves mostly 3–12 mm wide; spikes usually dense at maturity
